reviewText:
Update:  Originally I had not recommended this game, since multiplayer has been fixed, I can totally get behind it.  Worth the 3 dollars for the amount of fun you'll have.

Imagine, if you will, a game of battleship, except instead of trying to guess where their battleship is in an ocean, you're a mage that's chucking fireballs and floods at your opponent.  That's what this game is; wizard battleships.

There's no story as far as I can tell, but the gameplay and strategy can vary greatly depending on what rooms you are randomly given each turn.

Side note:  multiplayer (while fixed with the last update) is much like any other small game; pretty sparse but fun as hell when you find someone to play with.  More often than not, I'm playing singleplayer.  I will be picking this game up for some friends for a little gaming fun one night for sure.  Definitely worth looking into.
voteText: 24 of 29 people (83%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I think DT is a great game design. Needs more tune, far from perfect, but with some more work it could be great.
My Gf compared it to poker - half luck, half tactics.

Im mostly interested in the multiplayer part of the game.
Recently the main problem is the lack of balance. Its not rare when one player gets good stuff and the other nothing useful for long turns and loose without any chance. The randomness is far too high in this regard.
We found another problem when a game lasts too long (dozens of rounds). After a while its impossible to finish it in practice. The players get too much rooms and resources and neither of them can carry out an attack combo strong enough to win.

The software itself is very buggy now. Got 2 freeze in multiplayer from 8-10 games, randomised attacks try to damage rooms already destroyed in that round, sometimes the cancel button doesnt work etc. The execution is fairly weak now. Should be in early access.

You may ask if I listed a lot of problems with this game why I still recommend it? Cuz when it works its very enjoyable! There is every possibility to solve those problems and then it would be a really good little game for a fair price.

I hope the dev will solve the problems and let us enjoy this game as it really should be!

I will check back on and off and if needed I will change my review in the light of future development.

reviewText:
New Review:

The devs weren't sitting on their asses and actually did work. Well done! All issues i had were adressed and i can finally change the review to a positive one.

The utterly repulsive idea about FB integration was removed and tutorial made good and accessible, removing the confusion and allowing for somewhat enjoyable gameplay.

Developers have plans to improve the game, like many other progressive ones, like FTL or DOE at by the looks of it no additional cost. Raising their credibility and faith in them.

Notice that the patches arrived very early - clear sign of devs working to improve, maybe it was slow for some, but for small studios with limited personel thats absolutely fine.

So far ive seen the content to put the game on 4.5/10 or 5/10. And with the promise of improvement that will be easy 6/10.

Now to the core gameplay -> so far i have seen little change, but the gameplay mechanics were fine to begin with. Its not an AA type product but it has earned its space on steam. And i can only hope the developers will continue to strive for excellence.

Only thing left to improve upon would be perhaps sound? While Kevin produces high quality music, i feel that perhaps there should be a difference within the music depending on  how the game is going. You know how in FTL there is exploration and battle music? In Payday there is stealth/assault/stealth blown but no assault/planning style, - since the days of old there were changes to music in games differentiating depending on how the game goes. What im talking about is perhaps something like in Democracy 3 where there is vastly different music depending on how bad your situation is. I know its kind of a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ to ask but when tower is in flames, things are crumbling left and right and there is Vivacity" playing doesnt really set the mood. Then again the player who's base is up in flames and that track playing might still keep the positive spirit up.

reviewText: Dwarf Tower was a total disappointment.  Not only if Facebook integration required for basic gameplay, the menu interface is complete chaos.\n\nGameplay is bland at best, as all building and attacks are menu based.  With no clear cut goal other than the destruction of the enemy tower, Dwarf Tower seems like little more than a lackluster adaptation of Battleship.
voteText: 95 of 161 people (59%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Concept is great, building up in the air and down in the earth, while still trying to prepare for a fallback in case of a fire is great.
+ While your tower expands, so does your options. This game is great at training you to make the best of the resources at hand.
+ There's a good range of both abilities, but also items (/dwarves) that can counter those abilities. It leaves many opportunities to turn the game by moving your most crucial assets around, extinguishing fires, pumping out water, etc.

Cons:
- Not very original music, gets annoying quite fast (which is of course entirely subjective)
- No options menu whatsoever (including the possibility to turn off the music (I'm looking at you, devs)).
- Unfortunately, the multiplayer seems to be abandoned. It is probably best reccomended to play the game with some friends, since (even with the randomized aspects), after some time, I can imagine it will get a bit repetitive.
- Fires will â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you up.

All in all, I recommend the game for those of you who likes having to deal with the worst situation the best you can. With the missing options and died out multiplayer, I would normally not recommend it, but at the price of 2,99, it still have had more than enough replay value to make it worth my while.

//First review. Thanks for reading.//

reviewText:
Dwarf Tower is a simple game where you try to build your tower faster and better than your opponent while throwing spells at eachother. With simple gameplay and a small price, you will likely not be disappointed by it. While the gameplay is pretty good, and if you grab a friend you can have a good time together, it's not that big of a game that you can keep playing it over and over

The gameplay is simple and mostly intuitive. Build stuff, avoid getting wrecked, and sling spells at the opponent. The few issues are mostly ones that are a comfort issue. A lack of quick ways to select rooms and spells(The menu shows numbers, yet pressing number buttons on my keyboard does nothing, for some reason), and issues of being able to see just what is going on. Not the inteligence gathering way, that is, as you have spells and a room that help you identify rooms in your opponent's tower, but rather that as your tower is in front of your opponent's tower, your attacks will hit and the camera is trying to look at the action, but instead just zooms in on your own tower.
For some reason the screen goes completely black and shows only white text - quite a contrast with the normal bright sky behind your tower, and pretty annoying if you dont have mana or library/worker space. I'm not sure how that got through any sort of playtesting. At the same time, the options menu is severely lacking. They very clearly did not spend a lot of time on usability for the player.

With the rooms and spells that you get being randomised, you may experience a mild frustration as your tower burns down and there are no firefighters coming up at all for several turns. Luckily, with doors and clever building you can usually stop or slow the fire long enough to draw into what you need.
The graphics, as the screenshots show, are nothing to write home about. But they're functional and show you exactly what you need to know. The music is selected pretty well and overall it's a pretty good experience to play Dwarf Tower

That said, it is cheap, and it is small. Don't expect a huge game here, or a challenging AI to outsmart you. But if you grab a copy or two pack and share with a friend you can have a pretty good time for a few hours and get your money's worth

reviewText:
I love the music and artistic design, as they are very whimsical.

You play a mad dwarven mage, vexed by another of your kind who has had the audacity to blight your view with her or his tower on the hill just over yonder.

As your towers climb into the sky, you select kit to go into the rooms. This kit is either offensive or defensive in nature, and it will be used in your feud with the other dwarf who has decided to block your view with her or his phallic symbol, thrust erotically into the sky's tender loins. At some point, you begin casting spells, deploying rats and repairing your facility as your feud becomes a fight to the death, ending only when one tower or the other is toppled.

This game might also be read as a paen for two-dimensional urban planning.

Fun little game.

reviewText:
Great little casual game.  I like jumping in for just a quick game.  Its pretty random setup each time which helps to make each time you play unique.

The music is simple and enjoyable which is a first for me cause I usually always turn off the in game music for games I play.  In the Hall of the Mountain King is one of my favorite classical songs, so that alone gets the game a few extra points.  ;)  I would certainly not be opposed to more classical music for the game, course I also have 30+ classical music CDs which I can listen to while playing.  Heck I had In the Hall of the Mountain King playing in the background while writing this review.  lol

It could use some mouse over info for the items, but other than that, I don't really anything is wrong with the game.

I've only played single player.  I haven't done the tutorial or multiplayer yet.  I just really like to jump in, play a game or 4 and then jump out.

reviewText:
A really fun and simple strategy game with loads of replayability.
Games can last anywhere from a few minutes to up to an hour depending on how vigilant and stubborn you are.

I definitely recommend finding a friend/s to play with as the AI are a bit underwhelming.

Multiplayer has always worked pretty perfectly for me, regardless of where in the world my friend lives.

Overall this is such a unique game that you probably won't find anywhere else, and at such a low price what have you got to lose?

reviewText:
TL;DR: Good game, graphics/music not great, but overall good game.

Interface (Music/Graphics): 3/10. Majority of music is Kevin MacLeod's publically available music (ONE track). Majority of graphics is gray/beige/red, only other colours are in the room art.
Gameplay: 9/10. FTL-esque room management, base building is good, mana/dwarf resource management, that stuff.
Concept: 10/10. Build a dwarf tower with underground rooms, libaries, dwellings, etc etc. I love this.
Custom Content: 5/10. No Workshop, but 'Customize Deck' option that allows you to change cast cost, availability, and that stuff.
Overall: 10/10. Meep.

reviewText: I haven't played this for very long and it's already clear that Dwarf Tower is an appealing little game, halfway between a card-game and a wizardly version of battleship. It's simple to play, and to some extent you are at the mercy of the Random Number God, but it's genuinely fun and it seems easy to while away a little time on your own or with a few friends. Looking at older reviews, it also seems the developers are willing to listen to players, admit their mistakes and fix things promptly. There's little more I could ask for Â£1.99's worth of game, although mod support in the way of player-made tiles might be nice. I look forward to many happy hours of play and I wish all the best for the future of the developers.

reviewText:
This is a fun game. You are basically trying to build your archmage tower while at the same time trying to destroy your rival's and keep them from destroying yours. Interesting dynamics involved in figuring out how you want to build your tower and also in managing your spells and mana to cast spells.

You are given a random selection of cards each round, which you must use or lose. The cards are the spells, rooms, and tools that you need to build up your tower and your attack (and defense) capabilities. The spells are put in your library inventory until you use them, which requires mana points, which accumulate from crystals you build. (One thing that I would like to be able to do is remove spells from libraries. It can happen that you put a spell in there and later lack the space for a better spell available.)

I had some confusion at first how to play, but I gradually realized how the play is broken into segments. While it is obvious when you enter Build or Combat phase that it is time to build or attack, some of the sub-segments weren't so obvious: for example, that Pumping" was to assign some dwarves with this capability instead of actually pumping water out of a dungeon at that time. I think the game would be a lot more accessible to new players if there was a clearer demarcation between the segments of play
date: with perhaps a Help button to click on that describes what is happening in this segment of play.\n\nAll the basic information you need to play is in the game
recommended: even if it the information is presented in a manner that is a little rough around the edges. There is a tutorial that walks you through at least part of a game: my tutorial actually got stuck for some reason at some point
hoursPlayed: but I had seen enough to jump into a game. From what I did see
voteText: a little more direction from the tutorial on what is going on would be helpful.\n\nThe aesthetics of the game are simple but pleasing--I quite enjoyed the music and the simple artwork. I do kind of wish that you could see the little dwarves and archmages
helpfulPercent: especially when one of the archmages is defeated. But that is a very minor point and probably just a matter of taste on my part. (Actually it probably wouldn't work to show the archmage before the end because finding out where the archmage's quarters are is one of the points of strategy in the game.)\n\nI would definitely buy the game again after having played four rounds (each takes about ten minutes to play
votesHelpful: I think). I can see this game as one that I come back to from time to time for a quick archmage battle."

reviewText:
Music is relaxed and nice to listen too.
Graphics are minimalistic but working.

Gameplay is ... boring. Not because I dislike turnbased strategy (in fact I love that, and it was the reason for me to get this game). The problem with this game is that I as a player have next to zero alternatives.

Every turn I am dealt a hand of build and attack cards (I cant edit my deck). From this hand I can chose to build some rooms (3 different kinds), fill them with furniture (crystal, dwelling, library and very rarely a mirror) and load up the build rooms with repair and attack-cards.

And here comes the point where the game falls flat. When dealt room cards you always play them, because there is no incentive not too (as rooms are your hitpoints, due to many unaimed attacks the maxime here is bigger is better). The furniture gives me at least a litle tactial decisionmaking
date: as higher / lower placed rooms are more effective (store more spells) but are prone to some spells attacking from above (lightning) or from below (flood).\n\nThe spells are a no-brainer
recommended: as you usually store them all and fire them all
hoursPlayed: because why not? There is NO incentive not to use an attack
voteText: as storeing them yields you no benefit.\n\nAll in all the game is as tactical as throwing dice. If the game gives you good attacks you win

reviewText:
OK, let's get the bad out of the way first: This game feels unfinished, like it should have been labeled Early Access. The tutorial is quickly useless because it tells you to make a move that you can't make, and you can't skip past that part. There are little annoyances like a lack of a volume control and a user interface that is more complicated than it has to be. Worst of all, it's a two player game, and right now your only options are a computer opponent who is astonishingly easy to defeat once you figure out the basics or hoping that there's someone online waiting to play (and you have the perserverance to sit there watching a fullscreen window with nothing happening until someone does decide to play, as I don't think there's any special sound to alert you when a game starts, and if you alt=tab away you could miss the whole thing). The developer participates in the Steam forums, though, so hopefully he'll address these problems in an update soon,

But then there are the good things: The basic rules are somewhat easy to learn but reveal extra complexity as you play. There's the simple pleasure of setting up blocks to build your tower the way you want and the fun of knocking your opponent's blocks down. There's also strategy, including deciding whether to build defensively or to push your luck by stretching your tower out to great heights and depths in order to increase the power of the effects of the rooms you build... and thereby making an easy target to get the structure blown to bits and come tumbling down. The price is relatively inexpensive, which means even if you have to get an extra copy to give to a friend to ensure you have someone to play against it won't be too painful.

At first I didn't think I liked this game, what with the various problems mentioned above. But I ended up saying just one more gane" over and over until I realized I had played for several hours. If they ever fix the computer opponent's programming to be more challenging it will be a great solo game
date: but until then you'll want to find someone else to play against
recommended: because that's when the real fun begins."

reviewText: First Impressions:\n\nThe game is fairly enjoyable, though there are clearly some issues that still need worked out.  For starters, there is no options menu.  There IS an in-game options menu though it is sparse, not to mention that the music toggle does not work (I had to turn the sound down/off via my desktop audio mixer).  There's also no difficulty setting, though there is a sandbox and tutorial mode to help you get acclimated to the various rooms and their abilities.  The game itself is a mix of strategy and luck as the cards (rooms/abilities) you are dealt every turn appear to be random, though you do have to give some thought as to where they should go.  Crystals provide more mana and libraries hold more spells the higher up they are placed, for example.  All in all, a great filler" game and worth the $3...though like I said
date: it isn't perfect in terms of implementation and functionality.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rY3pzzc0lss"

reviewText:
Great little filler of a game with nice innovative mechanics and a just one more play compelling style of gameplay.

You'll like this if :
You like board games / card games - particularly filler type games
Like simple yet thoughtful no time pressure games
Like building things

You probably wont like this if :
You are looking for a deep dwarf fortress synergy game
Hate turn based games
Dislike random card drawing


This is a turn based strategy card game that would feel right at home on an actual game table top somewhere. A two player game, each player has a set of cards to play in a turn which consist of spells, empty rooms, dwarf assignments and room assignments. Build your tower" - with a mind to physics
recommended: floods et al - assign the rooms a role - to gain spell storage
voteText: or more dwarves to carry out tasks and attempt to destroy the enemies arch mage room before they can do the same to you.\n\nLike any such card game you are open to the whims of lady luck really giving you a bad day
helpfulPercent: but by and large the game is simple enough - and tactically varied enough - that luck shouldn't figure overwhelmingly for or against you.\n\nAn ideal type of game on its original platform - mobiles - but also a nice filler on a desktop for those odd 10 minutes. They should replace solitaire with this game..."

reviewText:
This game reminds me of old paper and dice games. Those are never any fun when you play by yourself but are a blast playing with others so I do feel I have been misled by the promise of a single player mode that doesnâ€™t just exist to existâ€¦
â€¦I would say avoid this game if you are only looking for a single player experience.

I really donâ€™t know what to make of Dwarf Tower as a single player game, and I cannot speak to how multiplayer mode works but I do have a few things to say about this game.

Here's a gameplay video on my YouTube channel.  My confusion is apparent at times.

YouTube: Dwarf Tower, Single Player, How, what & why?

First, my issues.  How dare you, as a game developer, force Facebook likes out a consumer (someone who paid for your product) to access to functionality with in a game.  There are all kinds of wrong in this, and I donâ€™t feel I need to go into the 'why', as this should be obvious.  All I have to say about this is â€˜I hope you enjoy your meaningless, dishonestly obtained likesâ€™.  Facebook likes should be gained on their own merit.

Second, the single player game is almost pointless.  The only challenge is to figure out what is going on. A broken tutorial, that left me no choice but to restart the application, was not any help.  I played through that tutorial twice and was lost until I figured out why it was broken.

Once you have figured out the game mechanics you just canâ€™t lose against the computer, and when you do win there is no level up, no new challenge and no improved computer player to test your skills and tower against. Itâ€™s all gone. Start again.

I really donâ€™t see any re-playability in the single player mode of Dwarf Tower.

On a more positive note, I think multiplayer mode may provide more of a challenge and more entertainment value.

If I were to make some suggestions that may improve the single player experience they would be:

A good game goes somewhere.  This is not the case in Dwarf Tower.  Start the game again after loss or a win. It would be nice to continue play in my newly constructed tower, maybe against a stronger or more capable enemy.

A good game teaches the player how to play while playing the game.  Levels would help here.  As a level one tower builder I would only get a limited number of pieces to work with. Once I have defeated the computer at least once, I would progress to a level two tower builder and get a few more parts to play with and so on.  The pleasure of the reward is what the gamer is looking for.

If you are going to have tutorial it should work. Swap the library and the crystal in your tutorial so I can finish it.  The single player mode demands some type of tutorial at this point and what is provided is inadequate.

There should not be a single player mode if it is going to suck. The gamer that is only looking for the single player experience is being misled. My single player experience did not make me want to play the game again and because of this an average gamer may never even try multiplayer mode.

Remove the tie-in to your Facebook account.  Enough said!!
This game reminds me of old paper and dice games. Those are never any fun when you play by yourself but are a blast playing with others so I do feel I have been misled by the promise of a single player mode that doesnâ€™t just exist to exist.  The developer has responded to a few Steam reviews to say that there are plans for a â€˜true solo mode with a storyâ€™ depending on the reception of the game, but as things stand now, I would say avoid this game if you are only looking for a single player experience.

My recommendation is purely based on the possibilities of the multiplayer mode.

GameFace

reviewText:
Dwarf tower is a little indie gem in the endless fields of AAA murder-everything-in-the-face games.

Set in a fantasy world, you are a mage with a ton of dwarf followers, dueling with an enemy mage.  You both build towers, use spells, and try to destroy eachother's archmage chambers.

Gameplay is an interesting turnbased strategy and physics gameplay.  No floating pieces of your tower unless they're connected to a levitronus.  Use doors and armor to keep out fire and flooding.  Fire spreads through your tower if it can, destroying anything and everything in it's path, so you need firefighters or doors.  Various other neat things.

The facebook integration that was there in the initial release DID kind of tick me off, but it has since been removed, letting me make this one of the *few* games where I would give a full 10/10.

The tutorial is pretty nice and decently explains the game, and the sandbox mode is nice for experimenting with building styles to see how they hold up to various attacks.  The music in use is some of Kevin MacLeod's awesome work, even if they couldn't get some custom music from him.

Overall, would give 10/10.

Also, just going to get this out of the way so I don't need to copy/paste a response everywhere: I was going mad on the reviews initially because the amount of people bashing the game for the same things, and not seeing that these things they were bashing it for were going to be removed the next update had me worried.  Given that the game got stupid amounts of negativity at launch, I was terrified it wouldn't make it to a stable point on Steam's stores.

And no, for those who are wondering, I am NOT related to the developers.  I'm just some guy who saw a little indie gem arrive on Steam, that I had been with for a bit of it's Steam Greenlight days, and I didn't want it to self-destruct because of a buggy launch.

That will be all...

reviewText: Get a friend and challenge them, hilarity will ensue!  -  11/10\n\nThis game is about strategy at its core but every game is so different that it never gets repetetive. It is usually a quick game with a match lasting on average 5-10 minutes (though I have experienced an hour and a half match, very fun). The games mechanics allow for some very funny situations as you scream and cheer at unexpected results of your rats, dynamite or lightning strike. All in all worth its price, even more so with a friend.

reviewText: Good game. Takes a few plays to work out what's going on, but is pretty clean and simple once you get your head around it. Long-term play value isn't high if all you want to try and do is beat the computer, but the fun lies in attempting to complete achievements, as it forces you to try and play in a manner that's not solely focussed on winning at all costs, which is frequently a harder thing to do, and that gives it more longevity than it would otherwise have.

reviewText:
Dwarf tower is a fun game where you and your opponent build mage towers and attempt to destroy the archmace's chamber of each others towers. To do this you have to store spells and dwarf actions and use them to break the enemy tower or fix your own. I found this game fun and although it is a bit repetitive, it was well worth the $3.

Basically this game is about locking yourself in your room and forcing librarians and dwarves to do your bidding. Oh yeah, and also...

FLOODS, EARTHQUAKES, LASERS, SHOVELS, RATS, AND FIRE!!!!!!!!!!!!! The other mages don't stand a chance.

reviewText:
TL;DR Simple, challenging, fun, best with a friend.

For the money they're charging (for two copies, anyway), this is a fantastic game. A great combination of both strategy and luck, with an incredible variety in how each game goes. You get given a set of cards each round to build with, along with spells and nasty things for your dwarves to get up to.

I've only played it a bit, but I'm looking forward to playing it heaps more.
